name: Discovery Quality Rubric - Enhanced with SPICED, Challenger, and Sandler
description: Evaluates discovery quality using 5 Wins framework enriched with SPICED (Situation-Pain-Impact-Critical Event-Decision), Challenger Sale (Teach-Tailor-Take Control), and Sandler Submarine (Pain-Budget-Decision discipline) methodologies for Fortune 50 technical sales

spiced.origin: Winning by Design - Modern product-led sales framework
spiced.key_insight: Reps who uncovered Impact sold 53% more than those focused on Pain alone

challenger_sale.key_insight: Challengers represent 40% of high performers in complex B2B sales
challenger_sale.best_for: Complex sales, multiple stakeholders, extended cycles

sandler_submarine.key_insight: Qualify Pain-Budget-Decision before presenting to avoid wasted SE time
sandler_submarine.best_for: Enterprise sales, Fortune 50 accounts, high-touch SE engagement

scoring_guide.90-100: Exceptional discovery - Deep SPICED coverage with Challenger insights and Sandler discipline. Rep taught new perspectives, quantified Impact, identified Critical Event, and qualified before presenting
scoring_guide.80-89: Strong discovery - Good SPICED foundation with some teaching moments. Mostly qualified before solutions. Minor gaps in Impact quantification or Critical Event urgency
scoring_guide.70-79: Adequate discovery - Basic qualification achieved but lacks depth. Minimal teaching, incomplete Impact exploration, or premature solution discussion
scoring_guide.60-69: Weak discovery - Superficial questions, jumped to demo before full qualification, missed Impact or Critical Event
scoring_guide.0-59: Poor discovery - Primarily presenting without understanding. No teaching, no Impact quantification, no qualification discipline

question_quality_and_teaching.description: Quality of questions AND ability to teach insights (Challenger Sale methodology)

excellent: Open-ended questions that uncover Situation, Pain, and Impact across all 5 Wins
Teaches customer something new about their business (Challenger insight)
Reframes customer assumptions about costs, risks, or opportunities
Questions reveal hidden costs or scalability limitations (e.g., Airflow technical debt)
Brings data/examples that challenge status quo ('teach for differentiation')
Follow-up questions dig into quantified Impact, not just Pain symptoms
poor: Only asks about Pain without exploring Impact or Critical Event
No teaching moments - purely reactive questioning
Accepts surface-level answers without probing for business impact
Jumps to solution before understanding full Situation
Generic questions that could apply to any customer
Focuses on product features vs. business outcomes

coaching_focus.spiced_situation: Establish full context before diving into Pain (tech stack, team structure, current processes)
coaching_focus.spiced_impact: Move beyond Pain to quantified Impact - what does poor orchestration actually cost them? (Winning by Design: Impact-focused reps sold 53% more)
coaching_focus.challenger_teaching: Bring insights customer hasn't considered - teach them about hidden costs, scalability risks, or industry trends they're missing

impact_quantification.description: Ability to quantify business Impact and identify Critical Events (SPICED methodology)

excellent: Quantifies current state costs (e.g., '40% of 5 engineers = 2 FTEs on maintenance')
Explores opportunity cost (strategic projects on hold, delayed revenue)
Identifies measurable Impact of solving problem (time saved, cost reduction, revenue enabled)
Uncovers Critical Event driving urgency (board deadline, regulatory requirement, competitive threat)
Validates that Critical Event is customer's driver, not seller's quota deadline
Paints vivid picture of positive outcomes with case studies or data projections
poor: Only discusses Pain without quantifying Impact
No exploration of what problem is costing them (time, money, opportunity)
Misses Critical Event or deadline driving decision timeline
Assumes urgency without validating real business driver
Vague outcomes ('make things better') without specific metrics
No connection between Pain and measurable business impact

coaching_focus.impact_formula: Current Pain × Time/Cost × Opportunity Lost = Total Impact
coaching_focus.critical_event_discovery: What happens if you DON'T solve this by [date]? What's driving that timeline?
coaching_focus.quantification_questions: How many engineers? How much time? What's the loaded cost? What revenue is delayed?

tailoring_and_control.description: Ability to tailor message to stakeholders and take control of conversation (Challenger Sale)

excellent: Adapts message for different stakeholders (technical vs. business vs. security)
Takes control by pressing on commitments and next steps
Comfortable discussing budget and money (not avoiding pricing conversation)
Uses customer verifiers to guide the sale ('Does that resonate?' 'Is this the priority?')
Reframes objections with teaching insights (e.g., Airflow hidden costs)
Sets clear mutual commitments (Challenger 'take control' not 'relationship builder')
poor: Generic pitch not adapted to specific buyer or business context
Avoids discussing budget, pricing, or commitments
Lets customer control conversation without guiding to business outcomes
Relationship-focused without challenging customer thinking
No verification that message resonates with this specific buyer
Passive about next steps - waits for customer to drive timeline

coaching_focus.tailor_by_persona: CTO cares about scalability, VP Eng about team productivity, InfoSec about compliance
coaching_focus.take_control_moments: Press for commitments: 'If we solve X, what happens next?' 'What's preventing us from starting POC?'
coaching_focus.money_conversation: Challengers are comfortable with pricing discussions - don't avoid budget questions

sandler_qualification_discipline.description: Discipline to qualify Pain-Budget-Decision before presenting (Sandler Submarine)

excellent: Explores Pain fully before discussing solutions or features
Validates Budget/financial commitment before technical deep-dives
Maps Decision process before building POCs or doing custom demos
Earns the right to present by completing Pain-Budget-Decision qualification
Avoids premature demos or technical discussions before qualification
Saves SE time by ensuring opportunity is qualified before heavy technical investment
poor: Jumps to demo or features before understanding Pain
Discusses technical solutions before validating Budget exists
Builds POCs or prototypes before understanding Decision process
Wastes SE time on unqualified opportunities
Lets customer drive to presentation before qualification complete
No discipline around 'earning the right to present'

coaching_focus.sandler_order: Pain → Budget → Decision → Presentation. Close each compartment before moving to next.
coaching_focus.pain_depth: Don't move to Budget until Pain is fully explored and quantified (Impact)
coaching_focus.se_time_value: For Fortune 50 accounts, SE time is precious - qualify thoroughly before technical investment
coaching_focus.no_premature_demos: Resist customer requests for demo until Pain-Budget-Decision are qualified

five_wins_enhanced.description: 5 Wins framework enriched with SPICED, Challenger, and Sandler principles

spiced_components.situation: Full context: current state, tech stack, team structure, existing processes
spiced_components.pain: Specific challenges and frustrations (emotional + rational business issues)
spiced_components.impact: Quantified business outcomes: time saved, cost reduction, revenue enabled, strategic projects unblocked
spiced_components.critical_event: Deadline or milestone driving urgency (Q2 planning, board review, regulatory deadline)
spiced_components.decision: Decision criteria, buying committee, approval workflow, evaluation timeline

challenger_elements.teach: Bring insights about hidden costs of current state (e.g., Airflow technical debt, scalability limits)
challenger_elements.tailor: Adapt message for exec priorities (CTO: scalability, VP Eng: productivity, CFO: TCO)
challenger_elements.take_control: Press on commitments, discuss budget openly, verify business case strength

sandler_discipline.pain_first: Fully explore Pain and Impact before moving to Budget or Decision discussions
sandler_discipline.budget_qualification: Validate financial commitment exists before building business case
sandler_discipline.decision_mapping: Understand complete approval process before presenting solution

technical_win.discovery_focus: Technical requirements, use case alignment, infrastructure, CI/CD - but only AFTER Business Win Pain is qualified (Sandler discipline)
technical_win.challenger_teaching: Educate on technical limitations of current solution (e.g., Airflow scheduler architecture, DAG complexity issues)
technical_win.sandler_timing: Deep technical discovery comes after validating Business Pain and Budget - don't waste SE time on unqualified opps

security_win.discovery_focus: InfoSec requirements, compliance needs, review process, questionnaire timeline
security_win.critical_event: Often the Critical Event - security review deadlines can drive entire sales timeline
security_win.sandler_timing: Identify InfoSec stakeholders and timeline during Decision qualification phase

commercial_win.discovery_focus: Scope, usage levels, support tier, services
commercial_win.sandler_budget: This IS the Budget discussion - validate willingness to invest before building custom proposals
commercial_win.challenger_control: Take control of pricing discussion - don't avoid money conversation

legal_win.discovery_focus: Legal review requirements, contract terms, procurement process
legal_win.sandler_decision: Part of Decision mapping - understand legal approval workflow and timeline

spiced_impact_excellent.quote: You mentioned 40% maintenance time. Let's break that down - that's 2 full engineers out of your 5-person platform team, right? At $200K loaded cost, that's $400K/year just keeping the lights on. But here's what I'm hearing you're NOT able to do: real-time pipelines, ML feature engineering, data quality framework. If you could ship even one of those, what's the revenue impact?
spiced_impact_excellent.analysis: Excellent SPICED Impact quantification: converts percentage to FTEs to dollars (Situation), explores both cost AND opportunity cost, connects to revenue Impact. Uses Challenger teaching to reframe from 'maintenance problem' to 'revenue opportunity problem.'

critical_event_excellent.quote: You mentioned Q2 roadmap planning in 3 weeks. Walk me through what happens if you go into that planning meeting without a solution for this infrastructure problem. What's the executive expectation? What projects get cut?
critical_event_excellent.analysis: Excellent Critical Event discovery. Validates this is customer's real deadline (not seller's quarter-end), explores consequences of inaction, connects to exec priorities. This is what drives urgency.

challenger_teaching_excellent.quote: Most teams running 500+ Airflow DAGs at your scale hit a wall around 800-1000 workflows. It's not just maintenance - the scheduler architecture fundamentally can't handle the concurrency. I'm curious, have you benchmarked your scheduler lag time during peak hours? Because that's usually the canary in the coal mine.
challenger_teaching_excellent.analysis: Perfect Challenger teaching: brings insight customer likely hasn't considered (scheduler architecture limits), reframes from 'we have a problem' to 'this problem gets exponentially worse', uses industry data to challenge status quo, ends with diagnostic question.

sandler_discipline_excellent.quote: Before we dive into a technical deep-dive or demo, I want to make sure we're solving the right problem. You've described the Pain - 50% of platform team time on maintenance. But let's talk about what it would take to fix this. If we could get that maintenance down to 10-15%, what investment would make sense? Are we talking $50K, $200K, $500K range?
sandler_discipline_excellent.analysis: Excellent Sandler discipline. Rep resists jumping to demo, qualifies Pain is worth solving, brings up Budget openly (Challenger 'take control'), uses ranges to gauge financial commitment before investing SE time.

sandler_discipline_poor.quote: That sounds challenging. Let me set up a demo next week and show you how Prefect solves this. I'll bring our Solutions Architect to walk through the architecture.
sandler_discipline_poor.analysis: Poor Sandler discipline. Rep jumps straight to demo/presentation before qualifying Pain depth, Budget, or Decision process. Commits expensive SE time without validation this is a real opportunity. This is how SE teams get burned out on 'tire kickers.'

weak_discovery_no_framework.quote: So you're looking for a workflow orchestration tool?
weak_discovery_no_framework.analysis: Weak discovery across all frameworks. No Situation context, no Pain exploration, no Impact quantification, no Critical Event, no teaching, no tailoring, no qualification discipline. Pure order-taking.
